item.title: One example of ploting Alluviam
item.description: 1.data input and pre-process 1.1Inputing the original data from local path library(readxl) library(dplyr) data <- read_excel("/Users/profits/Rdata/website/content/plot/2021-06-06-one-example-of-ploting-alluviam/data.xlsx") 1.2checking the data structure head(data) ## # A tibble: 6 x 16 ## sample soil_type location season longitude latitude pH ORP DO T ## <dbl> <chr> <chr> <chr> <chr> <chr> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> ## 1 127 R west rain 100°13′7… 25°37′5… 8.35 82 2.50 14.4 ## 2 57 R west dry 100°8′48… 25°46′2… 7.

item.title: Alluviam plot by ggalluvial-example 2
item.description: Let’s begin with a simple question:what is alluviam? Maybe you could find the answer in Creating Alluvial Diagrams and Alluvial Plots in ggplot2. Here you go, start your practice right now! And then the further question appears: when should I use it in my paper? From my limited experience, it would be a perfect solution if you want to illustrator your data by a flow-dynamic picture. Simplly, you could see it as a ribbon-connected stacked bar plots which located in parallel along a axis of variable.
